exercises.instruction: Complete each situation. Give two answers if asked.

items.prompt: Mia started writing her report three hours ago. She's still writing it. She has completed 4 pages. Write two answers: (1) activity, (2) completed amount.
We began painting the fence this morning. We're still painting. We've covered half of it. Write two answers: (1) activity, (2) completed amount.
Leo started learning Japanese in September. He's still learning. He's learned 300 words. Write two answers: (1) activity, (2) completed amount.
I started cleaning the kitchen at 6. It's still not finished. I've cleaned the sink and the table. Write two answers: (1) activity, (2) completed amount.

exercises.instruction: Make questions. Use present perfect simple or continuous.

items.prompt: Make a question: (you / wait / long?)
Make a question: (she / finish / the email?)
Make a question: (they / do / what?)
Make a question: (how many photos / you / take?)
items.canonical: How many photos have you taken?
accepted_variants: How many photos have you taken
How many photos have you taken?
how many photos have you taken?

items.prompt: Make a question: (why / he / look / so tired?)
items.canonical: Why does he look so tired? Has he been working late?
accepted_variants: Why does he look so tired? Has he been working late
Why does he look so tired? Has he been working late?
why does he look so tired? has he been working late?

items.prompt: Make a question: (you / ever / try / scuba diving?)
items.canonical: Have you ever tried scuba diving?
accepted_variants: Have you ever tried scuba diving
Have you ever tried scuba diving?
have you ever tried scuba diving?

items.prompt: Make a question: (how long / you / know / your neighbour?)
items.canonical: How long have you known your neighbour?
accepted_variants: How long have you known your neighbour
How long have you known your neighbour?
how long have you known your neighbour?

exercises.instruction: Complete with present perfect simple or continuous.

items.prompt: Look at your clothes! You ____ (paint) again.
I ____ (finish) my homework, so I'm free now.
How long ____ you ____ (live) in this town?
She ____ (write) three messages this morning.
He is sweaty. He ____ (run).
We ____ (work) on this project since Monday.
I ____ (not read) that article yet.
They ____ (argue) for an hour. Please stop them.
Someone ____ (break) the handle. It's loose now.
How many cups of coffee ____ you ____ (drink) today?
My phone is missing. I think I ____ (lose) it.
Sorry I'm late. I ____ (try) to find a parking space.
I ____ (know) her since we were kids.
The dog ____ (sleep) all afternoon.
I ____ (clean) the room and it looks much better.

exercises.instruction: Choose the correct option.

items.prompt: I (know / have known) Sam since 2015.
How long (are you / have you been) here?
We (live / have lived) in this flat for six months.
She (is / has been) ill since yesterday.
How long (do you wait / have you been waiting)?
I (have / have had) this jacket for years.
They (work / have been working) all morning.
We (like / have liked) this neighbourhood for a long time.
It's been noisy. The neighbours (have / have been) drilling.
I (am / have been) at this school since September.

accepted_variants: Have you known your boss long

exercises.instruction: Complete the answers.

items.prompt: A: Is Maya still in Berlin? B: Yes, she ____ there since March. (be)
A: Do you still play basketball? B: No, I ____ for years. (not/play)
A: Do you know Alex well? B: Yes, we ____ each other a long time. (know)
A: Are you tired? B: Yes, I ____ all day. (work)
A: Is your brother married? B: Yes, he ____ married since 2012. (be)
A: Is the internet down again? B: Yes, it ____ properly for two hours. (not/work)
A: Do you still live with your parents? B: No, I ____ on my own for a while. (live)
A: Are you hungry? B: Yes, I ____ anything since breakfast. (not/eat)
A: Is Tom still learning to drive? B: Yes, he ____ lessons for six weeks. (have)
A: Do you still have that old laptop? B: Yes, I ____ it for ages. (have)
A: Are you waiting for someone? B: Yes, I ____ here since 5 o'clock. (wait)
A: Do you like your new flat? B: Yes, we ____ it since we moved in. (like)
A: Is your sister a teacher? B: Yes, she ____ a teacher for ten years. (be)
A: Are you still watching that series? B: Yes, we ____ it all week. (watch)
A: Do you speak French? B: Yes, I ____ it since school. (learn)

exercises.instruction: Complete with for or since.

items.prompt: I've been studying English ____ two years. (for/since)
We've lived here ____ 2019. (for/since)
She's been on the phone ____ an hour. (for/since)
I haven't seen them ____ last summer. (for/since)
They've been friends ____ childhood. (for/since)
It has been very cold ____ three days. (for/since)
He's worked at this company ____ April. (for/since)
I've had this watch ____ a long time. (for/since)

exercises.instruction: Complete with ago / for / since where appropriate.

items.prompt: I bought this phone two days ____. (ago)
We moved to this flat a year ____. (ago)
Did you see him ten minutes ____? (ago)
I started this job in May, so I've been here ____ May. (for/since)
She's been waiting ____ 30 minutes. (for/since)
Itâ€™s been a long time ____ I last ate sushi. (since)

exercises.instruction: Write questions or short answers about time (how long / for / since).

items.prompt: Write the question: You started driving in 2020. (how long)
items.canonical: How long have you been driving?
accepted_variants: How long have you been driving
How long have you been driving?
how long have you been driving?

items.prompt: Answer: How long have you lived in this city? (since 2018)
Answer: How long have they been together? (for five years)
Write the question: The rain started at 3 o'clock. (how long)
items.canonical: How long has it been raining?
accepted_variants: How long has it been raining
How long has it been raining?
how long has it been raining?

items.prompt: Answer: How long have you had this bag? (for ages)
Write the question: She started working here last Monday. (how long)
items.canonical: How long has she been working here?
accepted_variants: How long has she been working here
How long has she been working here?
how long has she been working here?

items.prompt: Answer: How long have you known him? (since school)
Answer: How long have you been waiting? (for twenty minutes)

exercises.instruction: Use 'It's been ... since ...' or complete with since.

items.prompt: It's been three weeks ____ I last went running.
It's been ages ____ we met in person.
Rewrite using 'It's been ... since': I last saw her in June.
items.canonical: It's been since June that I last saw her.
accepted_variants: It is been since June that I last saw her.
It's been since June that I last saw her
It's been since June that I last saw her.
it's been since june that i last saw her.

items.prompt: It's been ten minutes ____ the bus left.
Rewrite: We haven't spoken for two months. (It's been ... since)
items.canonical: It's been two months since we spoke.
accepted_variants: It is been two months since we spoke.
It's been two months since we spoke
It's been two months since we spoke.
it's been two months since we spoke.

items.prompt: It's been a year ____ I changed my job.
Rewrite: The last time I ate meat was in 2019. (It's been ... since)
items.canonical: It's been since 2019 that I last ate meat.
accepted_variants: It is been since 2019 that I last ate meat.
It's been since 2019 that I last ate meat
It's been since 2019 that I last ate meat.
it's been since 2019 that i last ate meat.

items.prompt: It's been a long time ____ I watched a film at the cinema.

exercises.instruction: Use present perfect where it fits; otherwise use past simple.

items.prompt: I can't get in. I ____ (lose) my key.
The office is empty now. Everybody ____ (go) home.
I meant to call you last night, but I ____ (forget).
Helen ____ (go) to New York for a holiday, but she's back now.
A: Are you OK? B: Yes, I ____ (have) a headache before, but it's fine now.
Can you help us? Our car ____ (break) down.

items.prompt: Did you see Anna this morning? (It's 8 p.m.) -> past: I ____ her.

items.prompt: Rewrite with 'after': First he packed. Then he left.

exercises.instruction: Complete the sentences (used to vs now).

items.prompt: I used to cycle to work, but now I ____ (drive).
She used to be shy, but now she ____ (be) confident.
We used to meet every Friday, but now we ____ (not/meet) often.
I ____ to play piano when I was a child, but I stopped. (used to)
Did you use to read a lot? Yes, I ____. (short answer)
I didn't use to like tea, but now I ____. (do)
There used to be a shop here, but now there ____ (be) a bank.

exercises.instruction: Complete with be used to / get used to or used to.

items.prompt: I ___ used to getting up early. (be)
She is getting used to ____ in a new city. (live)
We weren't used to ____ so much noise. (have)
He used to ____ late, but now he's used to ____ early. (work / start)

They are getting used to ____ on the left. (drive)
I used to ____ a lot, but now I'm used to ____ at home. (travel / stay)

exercises.instruction: Use present continuous for future arrangements.

items.prompt: I'm ____ (meet) my cousin tomorrow evening. (arrangement)

They ____ (come) for dinner tonight. (arrangement)

exercises.instruction: Use present simple for timetables and schedules.

items.prompt: The train ____ (leave) at 6:15.

exercises.instruction: Present simple vs present continuous (future meaning).

items.prompt: A: What do you do on Saturdays? B: I usually ____ (work) until noon.
A: What are you doing on Saturday? B: I ____ (work) until noon. (arrangement)
A: What time does the train leave? B: It ____ (leave) at 7:05.
A: Are you free tonight? B: No, I ____ (meet) friends.

exercises.instruction: Choose present continuous (arrangement) or present simple (timetable).

items.prompt: The concert ____ (start) at 8 p.m. (timetable)

What time ____ the plane ____ (land)? (timetable)
We ____ (not/go) out tonight. (arrangement)
The library ____ (close) early on Saturdays. (timetable)
I ____ (work) late this evening. (arrangement)
The next bus ____ (leave) in five minutes. (timetable)
____ you ____ (come) to the party on Friday? (arrangement)
The course ____ (begin) on 1 September. (timetable)
We ____ (have) dinner with my parents on Sunday. (arrangement)
The match ____ (finish) at about 6. (timetable)
I ____ (not/meet) anyone tomorrow morning. (arrangement)

exercises.instruction: Complete with going to + verb (plans).

items.prompt: I'm going to ____ a new phone next month. (buy)
She's going to ____ medicine at university. (study)
We're going to ____ my aunt this weekend. (visit)
He isn't going to ____ tonight. He's too tired. (go out)
Are you going to ____ for the job? (apply)

exercises.instruction: Make predictions with going to (evidence now).

items.prompt: Look at those dark clouds. It ____ soon.
Careful! You ____ that cup.
The door is open. Someone ____ in.
He's driving too fast. He ____ an accident.
The glass is on the edge. It ____.
This bag is very heavy. It ____.
She's not looking where she's going. She ____ into the pole.
The battery is almost empty. My phone ____.
They haven't studied at all. They ____ the test.

exercises.instruction: Questions and negatives with (be) going to.

items.prompt: ____ you ____ to call him later? (question)
She ____ going to tell anyone. (negative)
I ____ going to argue about it. (negative)
What ____ they going to do this evening? (question word)
____ he going to sell the car? (question)

exercises.instruction: Complete with was/were going to (a past plan).

items.prompt: I ____ going to phone you, but I fell asleep. (was/were)
They ____ going to travel, but they cancelled. (was/were)
She ____ going to buy it, but it was too expensive. (was/were)
We ____ going to eat out, but we cooked at home. (was/were)
He ____ going to start the course, but he changed his mind. (was/were)
I ____ going to leave early, but the meeting ran late. (was/were)
They ____ going to watch a film, but the power went out. (was/were)
